 Jaffa in the movie.

I was watching the DVD Director's Cut -which was just released here- and in one of the cut scences you get a really good frontal of the two Jaffa that Ra is in a snit with for letting Daniel and co. get away. And you can see they don't have slits at their stomachs for the young Goa'uld's pouch. You can also see this in the cut version when Ra throws one of the Jaffa up against the wall. I was just wondering if anyone had any theorys on this.

 Glad you asked

Well, beleive it or not. In the Pilto for SG-1 O'Neill confirms that the Jaffa that were killed in the embarkation room are not he same as the people from Abydos. They were humans like us. Only Ra was Alien. To this day it has never been explained as to why they were different.

What it really is, is that the movie producers made Ra's guards humans that lived for a long long time because of Ra's technology. The Jaffa concept was invented by the writers of Children Of the Gods, probably when they conceived the Teal'c character.

I know it probably was a production slip, but they could easily come up with something to cover their asses in this case. It could have been that Ra freed the strongest Jaffa from their role as a Jaffa and brought them forth to become semi gods. They could be considered semi gods. This wouldn't make them as powerful as real gods (Goa'uld), but it would still give them a higher stauture than the Jaffa. Before the reformation of this forum I made a theory that Ra rewarded the strongest Jaffa from other system lords by removing their symbiote and placing them in a sarcohagus. A Jaffa without a symbiote who is placed in a Sarcophagus is returned to a human form (See episode "Hathor" where O'Neill is returned from being a Jaffa to a human again). I believe that Ra made these Jaffa feel privilaged by removing their symbiote and what not, re-humanising them and then making them feel good about what they are doing by raising them to a higher stature than that of a Jaffa. Demi God or semi-god would be appropiate. However, not all of his warriors were perfect and some had to be punished (see Stargate where a failed warrior is killed by Ra). Feel free to rip this theory to shreds. I will then re-digest it and make it even stronger than before.

Main problem I have with your theory is that the Goa'uld (I'd hav thought especially Ra), consider themselves way above humans. I mean if you imagine that Ra was served by ... I dunno, robots, or ... horses or something, you wouldn't bother 'reward' a horse, no doubt it's happy serving you. And a robot doesn't have feelings. This example is crap, but hopefully you get my point. Besides, Jaffa having a prim'ta (hey, that rhymes!) is beneficial to the Goa'uld; helps their kind to spread. So, it just doesn't seem he'd bother 'reward' them.

My example make any kinda sense?

The way I answered this was to say that Ra believed he was Special. He was the head Sysytem lord and anything that made him look different would be benficial. Whenever you see men who bears the resemblance of Jaffa because they wear Horus Guard and Anubis Guard Helemts, and they don't have puch slits in their stomachs then you can easily recognise ra's Personal Guards. You example is good venus, but Ra did not reward them for their benefit, but for his own benefit to make himself feel more special and unique as he would be the only Goa'uld to have a human personal guards. The Goa'uld are evil. They would say that his Warriors were being rewarded to keep them content. Just as the Jaffa believe they are being rewarded by their gods they are not. They are actually being used, but the Jaffa don't know this (or at least most of them don't).
